characters: TREMBLING HANDS, STRUGGLING TO LOAD A ROLL OF FILM INTO A
PRINCIPAL MERKIN "EXPOSED" IN THE PAGES OF "HEAVEN."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fly high above heavenly clouds.  Beneath a brilliant b sky.  A TEENAGED BOY'S VOICE greets us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On any given day, your life can change in the blink of an eye.  It's a clichй, I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Descending through the clouds, we are caught for a moment a dreamy gauze.  We emerge to find ourselves gliding abov small town.  Descending lower.  And lower.  To Xenia, Ohi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But a lot of clichйs get to be clichйs because they're true. Your life CAN change in the blink of an eye.  What I mean is, one day you're a regular chump, a wannabe something.  You're not even totally sure WHAT you wannabe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pass over the town square. A fine spring day in middle America. Red brick buildings with names like "Miller & So Drugs," "Two Sisters Gifts," "Nelson Family Market."   Yo can almost smell the rosy cheeks and moral fiber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The next day the doorbell rings and some stranger's holding your ticket to being SOMEBODY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still flying over the town, we focus on a TEENAGED BOY on Schwinn.  We follow as he pedals his way to...

dialogues.speaker: TECUMSEH HIGH SCHOOL
dialogues.text: A three story building.  Older, brick, sturdy.  Meticulou maintained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens every day.  Dreams come true.  And not just for those dim witted chain-smoking hillbillies you see on TV.  You know, the ones who win the Super Lotto and spend their fortune on a truck full of Goobers and a new set of front teeth.  It could happen to any guy, any time...even ME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JANITOR raises the American flag.  It flaps proudly as teenager chains his bike to a bike rack. He glances up at the flag, which is reflected in his uber sunglasses.  When he smiles, in SLOW MO, his teeth seem t sparkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, that's not me.  I'm over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SWISH PAN to another teenager, locking his bike.  Meet much less glamorous hero:  TED NELSON, 17.  A decent look kid.  Not hip enough to be cool.  Not square enough to be tormented. He joins the other KIDS heading into the schoo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're disappointed, I know. I admit, I was hopeless back then. The 'do, the shades, ugh. But I always had good taste in women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTY MALONE, 17, fills her cheerleader uniform in all right places. We watch her at her locker. Also in SLOW MO Which makes even her most mundane task seem graceful. Wow just look at her stack those books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Christy Malone.  Head cheerleader, love of my life, lust of my loins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy glances off screen and SQUEALS excitedly.  Anothe cheerleader enters the frame, holding a newspaper called "EXPOSED!"  Christy reads the headline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Health Teacher Flunks Her Own Lesson!"  No WAY!  It's Miss Pratt, smoking a doobie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy calls to Ted....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this, Ted! Imagine if we did THIS in the school paper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shows him "Exposed!" Ted gawks. Happy just to be this close to Christy. But they are quickly interrupted by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand them over! Immediately!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCIPAL RICHARD MERKIN, mid-50's, marches down the hall seizing copies of "EXPOSED!" from students' hands. We can that it is a "homemade" looking newspaper. And there's obviously much ado about it.  Christy winks at Ted as she hides the newspaper in her locker.   FREEZE FRAME ON Christy, WINKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that smile.  That wink. That's no platonic wink. That's a wink that says, "I don't just want you, Ted. I NEED you." So of course I had to ask her to the prom. I mean, she was practically begging for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted ambles toward Christy. Struggling for nonchalance.  S limbers up by stretching her leg high against the wall. S whispers to another CHEERLEADER.  They giggle.  Then Chri turns to Ted.  Flashing that perfect smile of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the guy I've been looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted wipes his sweaty palms on his jeans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking for you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy continues stretching.  Driving Ted crazy with her contortionist moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be awesome if we were about to say the exact same thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) From your lips, to God's ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies first.  I insist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. The prom's coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I was wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't have...I mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at him with gorgeous blue eyes. Then blurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy? Would you please please please take me to the prom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHUT UP!  Are you serious? Of course I will...of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy joyously jumps into Ted's arms.  Wrapping her leg around him in a passionate embrace.  The entire room APPLAUDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the most wonderful guy in the whole wide world, and I love you madly, Teddy Nelson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just as she's about to plant one right on his lips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shrill ringing of a TORNADO DRILL ALARM snaps Ted out his reverie. A large glass window separates Ted's EDITOR- CHIEF office from the rest of the school newsroom.  We realize now that Ted has only been gazing through the win at Christy, watching her stretch those gorgeous limbs of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.  A cheap trick, I know.  But it's my story and my fantasy. So cut me some slack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows the other students to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted joins his schoolmates, lining up on both sides of the hallway.  Far from any windows. They all know the drill.  Christy's just across the hall from Ted.  He can't take h eyes off of her. CHARLIE DUKE, 17, approaches Ted.  He's got a camera arou his neck and so much confidence, it's a wonder he can bal his head on his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, bro. Spare yourself the humiliation, the degradation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your pep talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get me wrong. We can salivate over all the Christy Malones of our lives. Wishing we could devour them like melt-in-your-mouth filet mignon. But we're strictly hamburger guys. Ground chuck, sixty eight percent lean, is about the best we can hope for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Charlie.  My best friend. He's into beef analogies, partly because he's a butcher's son, and partly because, well, he's just into beef analogies. What can I say? He's also a photographer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie kneels by the sidelines.  Shooting cheerleaders w his Nikon and an obscenely long lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a very gifted photographer.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH CHARLIE'S LENS
dialogues.text: A cheerleader's ripe buttocks, peeking out from beneath a short pleated skirt.  As she kicks and jumps, her little panties wedge themselves firmly between her cheeks. The camera skillfully tracks her movements, waiting until... The cheerleader's hand comes down.  In SLOW MO, her finge slips under her panties and tugs on the fabric, pulling i over her cheeks.  Charlie's motor drive whirls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The senior class voted him, "Most Likely To Have A Restraining Order Filed Against Him." But that's another story.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Ted and Charlie lean against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I genuinely think she wants me. I feel a vibe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That vibe is from your wrist, pal. You've been over-tenderizing your meat, again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy catches Ted's eye and smiles a perfect smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at everyone, Ted.  She's like a newborn with gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie secretly shows Ted a nudie magazine. "HEAVEN." A GORGEOUS WOMAN with perfect breasts graces the cover. A golden halo over her head.  Charlie flips it open.  Point a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only chick more untouchable than Christy Malone is Miss April.  (feminine voice) "Hi, my name's Ginger. I love tofu burgers, rainy nights, and riding bareback.  My biggest turn-off is cell phones during sex." Here's a tip:  set it on VIBRATE, honey, and don't be stingy with the lube.  (winking at Ted) Don't knock it till you tried it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you always this sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing for sure, Christy Malone ain't lookin THAT good naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted takes a peek at Ginger.  Then at Christy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday, I'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a better chance of being hit by a Mack truck with a refrigerated cargo bed full of sirloin tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted grabs the magazine and flips through more pages. Beautiful, naked women.  Palm trees. Blue skies. Bubbling Jacuzzis. Red Ferraris. The stuff that fantasies are made Ted looks determined...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I defy your hamburger theory of life, and all of the unfulfilled hopes and dreams it represents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's crazy talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I defy any and all limits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie can see the look in Ted's eyes.  He's about to do something bold and daring. Something he'll regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do it, Ted. Don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking away; defiantly) Any time, any day, a man can completely reinvent himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted starts to walk across the corridor, ignoring Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm warning you. This is an official warning. Danger, Will Robinson, danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quietly attractive teenaged girl, JULIE CONROY, watches Ted. She seems concerned, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one more person you should meet. Someone integral to my story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Julie Conroy. Unlike the rest of these losers, she didn't grow up in Xenia, Ohio. I just met her that day. But already, she had made a difference in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teachers mill around.  Chatting. Snacking on donuts, coff PRINCIPAL MERKIN bursts in, spilling a stack of "EXPOSED! onto a table. Everyone freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Pratt, Miss Pratt! What were you thinking?  How could you be so careless? (reading) "Exposing Hypocrisy in the Morons who Teach Us." That's the little bastard's motto!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teachers turn to MISS PRATT.  We recognize her from t cover of "EXPOSED!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (summoning courage) Principal Merkin, I realize we have to teach the children that recreational drugs are the devil's work, but that doesn't mean we don't dance with the Prince of Darkness ourselves, every now and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, well, bravo!  That's just what we'll tell the school board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, an AIR VENT pops open and CRASHES on top of a coffee machine.  THE WHOLE ROOM, IN SHOCKED SILENCE, turn look at... JULIE, her head framed by the air duct.  She holds a digi camera in her hand. Her expression says: "Oh, shit." Principal Merkin narrows his eyes at the "little bastard" has been making his life hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie sits in a chair in front of Ted's desk. She and Ted size up one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merk's punishment was cruel. Expulsion without appeal. Or working for me on the school paper. The school paper would be torture for a gonzo reporter like Julie and we both knew it. But what choice did she have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie leans back on the chair, rests her feet on Ted's fi and blows a huge bubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, William Randolph. Your last big scoop contrasted the popularity of Rice Crispie Treats and chocolate Snickerdoodles at the annual bake sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just one example. My reporting has made a difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me guess: retail sales of little chocolate sprinkles have gone through the roof!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school dumpsters used to overflow to the point where the stench was unbearable. My award winning exposй changed all that. The city added an extra weekday trash pick-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie deadpans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true? Is ignorance bliss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I loved "Exposed!" and I hate it that you got busted. I know the school paper sucks in comparison, but it's really not THAT BAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's eyes wander to Christy, who prances around the newsroom.  Julie notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even tell me you're hot for Miss Titty Pom Poms over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy's a very talented journalist. I see a Pulitzer in her future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know they gave them for Best Lip Gloss Retention During a Blow Job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me-ow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Ask her to the prom. Get it over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have absolutely no intention--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Do it. I triple-dog-dare you.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Ted nears Christy.  Students stare as he passes.  They el one another.  Whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you see, this is really about a triple-dog-dare. I don't even know what it means. I just know, unless it's a felony, a triple-dog-dare pretty much has to be met with immediate action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted seems unaware that all eyes are upon him.  The cacoph of the corridor settles.  He gets down on one knee in fro of Christy.  Christy looks down on Ted.  Smiles that smile.  Which fre as her eyes dart.  Realizing that everyone is staring at with great anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Christy, I was wondering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOULD YOU GO TO THE PROM WITH ME?!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corridor explodes with LAUGHTER.  Ted flushes with embarrassment.  Christy looks mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through gritted teeth) Ted, have you lost your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like me. I like you. I guess it's pretty obvious to everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't LIKE you. We're JUST FRIENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ted, DUH.  I smile at everyone since I got my braces off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll think about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy laughs derisively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really don't get it, do you? I am genetically programmed to desire a big, buff, manly man who can defend and provide for me and my yet to be conceived offspring!  It's, like, a caveman thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's a maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answer is NEVER, Ted, NEVER. Except maybe in your dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy flees. Leaving Ted kneeling there. Alone. Unless count the hoards of STUDENTS who are watching and LAUGHIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my dreams.  Of course. (repeating; chanting) This is a dream.  This is only a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie approaches.  Gives him a hand.  Helps him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ted.  This is an actual emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted pukes in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to warn you, William Randolph. She's got stiletto heels hidden in those Keds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you triple-dog-dared me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was for your own good, in a twisted sort of publicly humiliating way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One word, my friend. One word. MEATLOAF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted lifts his head.  Looks in the mirror.  Distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's gotta be more to life than meatloaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a hair above middle class. Home sweet home nonetheles Dinner in progress. MOM, DAD, Ted, younger brother, JIMMY mutt named CORKY curled under the table. A storm brews. Lightning in the distance. Thunder RUMBLES. Ted's Mom observes her son with unmistakable Mom-radar. S slides a slab of - rotten timing! - MEAT LOAF onto his pl with an unpleasant thud. Ted shudders...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I never eat another bite of meat loaf again, it'll be too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's Mom frowns. Jimmy explains matter-of-factly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad. Meatloaf has come to represent all that Ted hates about his mediocre life and the world we live in. He's what you'd call clinically bummed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't we have pot roast or stroganoff or even a little London broil? I mean, for god's sake, we own a grocery store!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's parents look at one another, shake their heads. His gently explains...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard about Christy, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy tries to stifle a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Does everybody know everything I'm about to say or do every freakin' minute of the day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cursing in this house, young man. Use the strong vocabulary God gave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a shred of privacy in this whole stupid town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We understand your disappointment, Teddy. Christy is a pretty, sexy, provocative, voluptuous... (catches himself) We...uh...we understand your disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my private business! Mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can the tantrum, sweet pea. We're the good guys, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad. Don't allow this disturbing behavior to furrow your collective brow. Ted's just experiencing some post-adolescent turmoil, coming to terms with the whole "small town dynamic."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate Xenia! I hate my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted charges for the front door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And until that moment, this was the worst day of my seventeen and a half years. And then it happened. Three, two, one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted bursts outside and plows straight into MARTY ZUKERMAN short, rotund man in his mid-50s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Sorry, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zukerman's briefcase and papers are knocked to the ground Ted helps to retrieve them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a hurry, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the middle of a melodramatic exit. It wouldn't really make a statement if I tiptoed out the door...What are you selling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People pay good money for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just a messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted starts to back away. Instinctively knowing the bad ne must be for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. No way. I've had all the bad news I can take for one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about your parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stops. Puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terrible at this. I blurt. I'm a blurter. Your parents...They ...well...they exist no further. (off Ted's confusion) Skinny-dipping. The Amazon. Piranhas. It wasn't pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got the wrong guy. The closest my parents have been to the Amazon is the Brazilian pavilion at Epcot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well kid, I'm speaking of...your biological parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sits on the couch, bewildered. Dad beside him. Mom po coffee in her best china.  Zukerman regards a wall of fam photos as he takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The will reading is next Tuesday. Naturally all of Ted's expenses will be taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's parents look worried. Mom reminds Dad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a truckload of strawberries arriving on Tuesday morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining to Zukerman) We own a small family grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How quaint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly; moping) It's spring break. I don't want to go to a will reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's part of growing up, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Having spring break ruined by will readings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what your mother means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I can give you two tickets, prepaid, but you must be there. There's no other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad. Allow me to accompany Ted. I can assure you, I'll be the level-headed sidekick to your angst ridden teen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Ted should take someone older, more responsible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Charlie?  You boys could make it a little adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, at a will reading? What did I do to deserve this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning strikes again.  Thunder rumbles a second later. The lights flicker. And it's PITCH BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candles light the dark room. Rain pours hard outside. Journalism mementos all over Ted's walls. News clippings. Magazine covers. There's even a faux Pulitzer, a Christma gift from his parents. Ted's Dad sits on the edge of his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember spring break of my senior year.  Seems like a lifetime ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa was so strong back then. Working from the crack of dawn. So proud of his peaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember how you struggled through that whole facts of life talk and then found out I knew more than you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're way ahead of me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proving it...) It was the year of the rhizopus rot. Grandpa almost lost the farm. You sacrificed your dream to go to the prize hog festival. And in the end you saved the peaches and you didn't have to slaughter your sow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lesson being?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you have to do stuff you don't want to do. It's all part of growing up. And it usually works out peachy in the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting so good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad chuckles, but Ted's still moping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are my parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't want me when I was born. Why should I care...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if they're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had a rough life. Your father was a bouncer. Your mother was, well, a two-bit stripper. There was no place for a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did do one great thing. They gave us our boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be a sport. How bad could spring break in Los Angeles be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we could go to Disneyland or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it as a rite of passage to manhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like one of those "National Geographic" specials with the topless chicks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever helps you cope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's better than having tribal patterns carved in my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ya go. Always remember, focus on the peach...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if this is what it feels like to be born?

dialogues.text: Think about it...Long tunnel, bright lights, it's full of vaginal symbolism.

dialogues.text: Poor Freud, turning in his grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, it's like we're being reborn. We really could reinvent ourselves here, just like you said. Nobody knows about your massive humiliation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Dad said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Charlie sit on opposites ends of the plush interi Charlie eyes the control console with its slew of gadgets They practically have to shout to hear one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A bouncer? Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he got promoted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie continues playing with the console switches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late.  Rock music pulsates through the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) This is the life, baby. We get ourselves some tail and we're talking SPRING BREAK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Wait a second, I thought we were hamburger guys.

dialogues.text: POP! The cork flies through the air.  Bounces off the ceiling.  And hits another switch.  The sun roof glides o Champagne overflows from the bottle.  All over Charlie's crotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice. Is that in the limo etiquette handbook, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie grabs a bar towel as Ted looks toward the sun roo Beautifully blue Southern California sky greets him.  Wit occasional palm tree swooshing by.  Ted rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's head peeks out of the sun roof. Tentatively. Unsure takes in the sights as the limo cruises Sunset Boulevard. People stare at him. A beautiful BLONDE smiles and waves. waves back, very timidly. Charlie sticks his head out, too. Sun on their faces. Win their hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo passes through the ornate gate of what could onl a sprawling mansion. It comes to a sudden halt. The door swings open to reveal a group of BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOMEN. C in very short black dresses and even some black bikinis. expressions on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The beautiful young women guide Ted towards the mansion. Charlie follows. A particularly VOLUPTUOUS BEAUTY eyes hi curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Charles. The handsome, devoted best friend. We're so close, we feel each other's pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voluptuous beauty notices Charlie's soaked crotch. He winks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, the spry HELEN McDOLE, 60s, emerges from the mansion.  She approaches Ted and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my, he would have been so proud.  You're the spitting image of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never spits, ma'am. Ever. He can't even get a good hocker going. I've tried to teach him. It comes from the diaphragm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply; to Charlie) You're on the next plane home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted takes a seat at the spacious conference table.  Helen sits on his right. Charlie sits on his left.   Zukerman and two other IMPATIENT ATTORNEYS wait at the he of the table.  Finally Zukerman checks his watch and rise

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're running out of time. The kid's here. We don't need HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very dramatically, Zukerman slides a copy of "Heaven" magazine down the conference table. Right to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with "Heaven?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seventeen. I know it like the back of my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your fathered owned the entire "Heaven" empire.  You own it now. Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's stunned, speechless. Charlie gawks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything?  The publishing division, the real estate holdings, the retail outlets, the theme parks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zukerman presses a remote control.  A wall panel slides o to reveal a large monitor which springs to life.  On the screen is a striking couple.  Ted'S BIOLOGICAL PARENTS.  HEATHER and TOM DEEDS. Heather, stunningly sexy and overflowing from her gold sequined halter top. Tom, very handsome in a Vegas showman sort of way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sweetheart! We wish we could be right there to hug the living daylights out of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you're watching this, then it means we bit the dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're anything like yours truly, then you probably figure we didn't want you when you were born, so who cares if we're dead? Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks guilty. This is too weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we did want you. It's just that you don't always get to keep what you want. We knew you needed a real mom and dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had no idea the nudie magazine we started in the garage would turn into all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heather holds up the first issue of "Heaven." She's on th cover, wearing nothing but a halo. She looks almost exact the same today, with a few extra nips and tucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe that was me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we knew it, we created the most popular men's magazine in the entire nation. The rest is history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So here we are. Dead. But we never want you to want for anything. That is, we want you to have everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heather leans forward and blows a kiss into the camera. H strongest assets spilling forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We love you, Ted. We always did. We always will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's practically slobbering. He elbows Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe that's your mother. We're talking babe-a-licious chub fest, right here in the 501's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a broad smile) Every morsel of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would appear so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smashing!  Welcome to the family, Ted. You are going to breathe some new life into this place. You are going to set the world on fire! You are going to...call me Uncle Billy? Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Uh, sure. Uncle Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have only one concern...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted waits. Swept up by Uncle Billy's spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do like girls, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I like girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot? I mean, a whole lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As much as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the rescue) He likes them with the unbridled enthusiasm of a seventeen-year-old virgin who's been making mental beef jerky since he saw the bevy of tender young skirt steaks at his new hacienda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy grins broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy leads Ted and Charlie through the cavernous r Sexy, semi-clad oil paintings of Ted's biological mother adorn the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parties are held in here when the weather dips below seventy. Which is seldom.

dialogues.text: Seldom? No kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orgies, exactly. Take a deep breath. You can smell it. Pure sexuality, oozing from the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The epitome of every boy's dream arcade.  Everything from classic pinball machines to the most high tech virtual reality game that has yet to hit the market.  Charlie sha his head in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naked girls, wild sex, video games. No wonder it's called "Heaven."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a fun place...but we don't usually come here until after the orgies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) Ah, in other words, this is the apres-orgy salon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed it is. During the day, visitors prefer to be outside, au naturel. As it were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie continues to gawk. Ted's equally impressed but holding it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy leads Ted and Charlie by the indoor pool whic decorated like a tropical pond, complete with exotic vegetation, lava rocks, and a waterfall.  They pass throu cave-like entrance and find themselves...

dialogues.text: Hello, girls! Have you met Ted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is like my every wet dream come true.  I don't even care that you're here, too, bro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be cool. Fake it if you have to.

dialogues.text: Good advice, Ted. You have your father's instincts.

dialogues.text: Just remember, you're not the man you were a day ago. And these girls, let's just say they'd be eager to please you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted gulps. It's hard to believe this is real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how many of them will be at the orgy tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't some 80's porno film, you dip shit. There are no wild sex orgies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. Maybe not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not ever. Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never say never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, god.  Look. Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really love your peaches, wanna shake your tree.

dialogues.text: Maybe she needs help, Ted. You should be a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (having a moment) Oh baby, yes, yes, yes. Fuck me like you mean it.

dialogues.text: Ted elbows Charlie out of his fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kiss your mother with that mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd kiss your mother with this mouth. I mean, if she wasn't, you know...

dialogues.text: He means dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far away? In Xenia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, whatever.

dialogues.text: Mom waits nervously for the phone to ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad hurries out of the bathroom, hiking up his pajamas. M speaks loudly, as if Ted's in Siberia.

dialogues.text: How are you, baby? Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A palatial suite. Very Louis XIV.  Ted throws a sheet ove nude sculpture of his biological mother. While holding a cordless phone in the crook of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right, Mom. I'm not in Siberia, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a nice flight?  Are they taking good care of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Just say it, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know they were simple people, but did this trip help your college fund at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, let's just say I can buy anything I want in the whole bookstore. Including the bookstore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not getting it) Well, good. Every little bit helps.

dialogues.text: Suddenly, Charlie bursts into the room with a pair of binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check this out.  Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better go, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see you soon.  Have fun in... (trying to be hip) ...the land of fruits and nuts.

dialogues.text: Charlie flips off the light switch and whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: A devastatingly PERFECT WOMAN, GINGER, "Miss April,"  eme from the pool, wearing nothing but a g-string. Her skin shimmers from the reflection of the pool lights. Rivulets water stream down her body.  She reaches for a towel and her body dry. An incredible aura seems to surround her.  Separating her from the other spectacular beauties we've already. Ted lowers the binoculars. Entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get it now. You and me. We're dead.

dialogues.text: Dead?

dialogues.text: Our plane crashed. In the Grand Canyon. A big fiery explosion. We never made it to L.A. They needed dental records to identify us. And this place. This. Actually. Is. Heaven.

dialogues.text: Then there must be a whole room, made completely of chocolate.

dialogues.text: And some really fast cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Charlie move like thieves in the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be such a pansy. All of this is YOURS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lot to digest. Imagine how you'd feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd feel like staying up all night! Forever! Or at least till I got the LAY of the land, SO TO SPEAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Charlie enter.  Flip the light switch.  It was hi parents' very opulent bedroom. Complete with more risquй paintings of Ted's biological mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I'm entering a forbidden tomb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...where they get all the really good porno channels on cable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cha-ching. Jackpot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a whiff of heaven.

dialogues.text: How would you like it if I did that to your mother's panties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd call you a sick, twisted fuck.  But this is different.  She wasn't your mother mother--

dialogues.text: Give me those!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted grabs the panties just as Charlie pulls away, ripping them in half. Just then the door opens to reveal a very proper ENGLISH BUTLER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do apologize, sir. I heard a noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Charlie awkwardly hide the panty halves behind th backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I completely understand, sir. I'll leave you to your business. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Butler leaves.  Ted glares at Charlie. Who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of boys fighting over a pair of red silk panties is nothing compared to what he's seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yeah, he's probably been serving cocktails, SO TO SPEAK, at the orgies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage is crowded with two dozen sporty classics. Ted runs his hands over the hood of a red Ferrari 575M Marane He pulls the door open and slides into the leather seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna take me for a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted turns around and spots Ginger, the goddess from the p making her way towards him.  He gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I don't have the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the ignition, silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted glances down. There they are. She hops in next to him He doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do know how to drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have much experience with a...uh...stick.

dialogues.text: Ted blushes. He needs a lot of lessons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press your left foot on the clutch.  And turn the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now release the brake. And slide the stick into first gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginger moves her slender fingers on his knees. Showing hi how it's done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now very carefully apply some pressure to the gas pedal with your right foot as you release the clutch with your left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She squeezes his thigh and winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ferrari jerks out of the garage and promptly stalls. Ginger giggles.  Could Ted be MORE embarrassed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first time can be awkward. You just have to get on and try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know if I should be doing this. It's a very expensive car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your car. These are all your cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of them have to be automatics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father liked shifting. He said it brought him closer to the engine. "Like a woman, purring with ecstasy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted feels his temperature rising. He changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ted, by the way. I think I forgot to say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I'm Ginger. Miss April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one with the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I almost didn't recognize you without...you know...that stallion between...your...uh...legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginger blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounded so much better in my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginger GIGGLES. Ted tries to hide behind his less than co shades. Ginger notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ted. Wanna go shopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shopping, really? I should tell my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  He found the chocolate room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big grin) Hi ho, Silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the car in gear.  The tires scream as they take o Gears grind as he shifts. Not exactly purring with ecstas Yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ferrari negotiates its way along Rodeo Drive. Ted see to have gotten the hang of it. Tourists stare.  One snaps a photo. Ted pulls up to...and then over...the curb. Well, he almo has the hang of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted emerges from a dressing room.  Slowly starting to los his boy-from-Xenia taint.  He glances at the price tag, dangling from his sleeve.  His eyes widen. Ginger strokes arm. Whispers seductively in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father always said, "Money matters only to the man who doesn't have it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted listens. Trying to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted tries on some snazzy sunglasses.  Ginger approves.  T still checks the price tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, habit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginger looks into his eyes. As if she can see his soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who exactly ARE you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) What do you mean? I'm Ted Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who IS Ted Nelson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's not sure how to respond. He smiles awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a small town boy, destined to live an ordinary life with an ordinary wife and a tiny house with a boring old white picket fence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hamburger life. Now he can defy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or do you have a taste for the good life, Ted? It's in your blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always knew there was more. I felt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then remember, you are the heir to a billion dollar empire. You have a staff of literally thousands. Multiply everything you ever imagined by a million and you still can't even wrap your head around everything that is yours. ALL YOURS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted slides on the shades. Slowly, purposefully. He grins the SALES CLERK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the whole case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, Charlie, Helen, and Uncle Billy walk past GRAPHIC DESIGNERS in cubicles as Helen leads a tour of the "Heave magazine offices. As they pass each cubicle, HEADS pop up check them out.

dialogues.speaker: "HEAVEN" WAR ROOM
dialogues.text: POLAROIDS OF NAKED WOMEN cover every square inch of wall space.  Ted and Charlie gawk.  Who can blame them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every one of these women thinks she should be the next Angel of the Month. It's your job, Ted, to decide which of them is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it isn't straight by now, son, you probably should see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are real, live women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winking at Ted) We don't generally feature blow-up dolls in our magazine. But hey, if you think there's a market for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I love being dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted focuses on one particular picture. He removes the pus pin that holds it to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see the concerned look on Helen's face. Does this have any taste at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Nice choice. There's only one problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shows Uncle Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think she upgraded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They went in through the belly button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy nods. He explains gently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't allow TIPN, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tipping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIPN. Tattoos, implants, piercings, nose jobs. Our angels must be pure, unadultered, completely natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks at the walls again. Carefully. He has a knack f this. He hands a picture to Helen. She turns to Uncle Bil and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emotional) You have your father's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His father. He just can't get used to that. Who was this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks at the impressive collection of suits. Runs his hands along the fabrics. Picks a particularly stylish jac and tries it on. It fits poorly. Too big in the chest and shoulders. Ted looks at himself in the full-length mirror He's not half the man his father was. Suddenly there's a KNOCK on the door. Ted quickly takes o his father's jacket and puts on his own. He lets Uncle Bi in.  LOUD PARTY SOUNDS momentarily pour into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, Ted-baby. Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Everything's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's struggling with a silk tie. Uncle Billy helps him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready for your big coming out party? Everybody's dying to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a couple of finishing touches. My parents always said you never get a second chance to make a good first impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) They said that? Really? (realizing) Oh, your parents. The Nelson's. Right, right. How midwest. I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted wipes his palms on his slacks. Confiding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truth is, I'm a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU? Nervous? Why on earth should you be nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All those people out there. It's a lot of pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh! You laugh in the face of pressure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a multi-media magnate. The Tycoon of Tits. The Baron of  Bottoms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted chuckles. Uncle Billy's calming him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the Emperor of every little girl who dreamed of growing up to see her naughty bits spread eagle, airbrushed to glossy perfection, with staples through her ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy rubs his shoulders. As if pep-talking him for big fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the Sultan of Semen. The Monarch of Masturbation. The Merchant Prince of Lust. You. Ted. Are the King of Coitus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? The King of Coitus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Supreme Sovereign of Sexuality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. But...that's the thing... (he whispers) I've never even actually...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Why, look who's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy swings the door open to reveal. KIKI and KELL Tall, beautiful, leggy IDENTICAL TWINS.  They smile warml Ted, each offering an arm.  Ted holds his head high. Like Sovereign of Sexuality.

dialogues.speaker: LONG DRAMATIC STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: With the twins on either side of him, Ted struts down the stairs and into a sea of people.  All so eager to meet hi Ted acts as if he's been doing this all his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) The Potentate of Poon has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And instantly, he's surrounded.  People shake his hands.  Women kiss his cheeks.  Athletes, movie stars, models.  Charlie watches, beaming proudly.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Charlie thinks he's Travolta. Dressed for disco. Twirling Super Model. Ted dances among a dozen BEAUTIES.  They ste kisses and hugs, here and there. A thousand Cinderellas, after one Prince Charming.  Ted's having the time of his life. Charlie dances up to him. Shouting in his ear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't life amazing? A week ago, you couldn't get to second base!  Now you OWN second base!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They high-five one another. An EXOTIC BEAUTY grabs Ted an starts dirty dancing. Rubbing herself against him.  Ted's clueless. So he improvises.  People cheer him on.  He thr his pelvis. Feigns various sex acts. Hilarious, goofy, bu works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party's over.  Ted relaxes in the Jacuzzi, sipping champagne. Thrilled, elated, blasted.  Uncle Billy sits across from him.  Two MASSEUSES tenderize their shoulders But as the scene continues the women take an even greater interest in each other. Stealing a kiss here. A touch the Ted attention is distracted as he chats with Uncle Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you you could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was like a different person tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the new and improved you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have been laughed right out of Xenia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one will be laughing at you now, Ted. You can take that to the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really going to be strange going home in a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ARE home. But go ahead, finish school, do what you feel you need to do. In the meantime, I'll be your point person here on the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? You'd do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been very lazy for a long, long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem like you're anything but lazy, Uncle Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confiding) I never finished school myself. Never had to. My brother built this empire from nothing but his wife's perky tits and a whole lot of gumption. He gave me a cushy job on a silver platter. I never struggled for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents always say hard work builds character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like I didn't have ideas, I had plenty of ideas. But I never even shared them with your father. Never had the guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...for one thing...I think it's despicable that we exclude so many women that only fit our western notion of "classic beauty."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think we should be more open minded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is a big, beautiful place.  We can open new markets in Africa and Asia.  Imagine the Dali Lhama reading our magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, our scope is too narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At our press conference tomorrow, I think we should announce our plans to explore the world. Not just a few leggy 36D's, with blond hair upstairs and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Masseuses help Uncle Billy out of the Jacuzzi. They s their goodnights and Ted closes his eyes. When he opens t Ginger stands at the edge of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted can barely nod. She unzips the back of her dress and it fall to her feet.  The silhouette of her nude body is startlingly gorgeous in the moonlight. Ted watches as she descends, step by step, into the frothy water. Ted's paralyzed with desire and fear. Ginger descends dee A wash of foam caresses her breasts.  She continues.  Unt she's completely submerged. Ted looks startled.  The "Jaws" theme echoes through his ears.  He starts to rise. Concerned. When suddenly, he fe something.  Whoa! His swimming trunks land next to him. He starts to rise out of the Jacuzzi, when suddenly he's sucked under.  He thrashes.  His hand grabs the edge of t Jacuzzi. But his fingers give out.  And he slides under. to rise out of the water with Ginger. Attached to his lip Kissing him passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Ginger in bed.  Morning rays, satin sheets, what night.  Ted awakens.  He stares at Ginger in awe, remembe what happened. Smiles big. Ted slides out of bed.  Catches his reflection in the mir Takes a good look at himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (posing; cool) Who's your daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press Conference. Lights, cameras, reporters, bedlam. Unc Billy, Helen, and Ted sit at a makeshift dais.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My brilliant, extraordinary nephew, Ted Nelson, has brought enough fresh blood to this company to make all of Transylvania happy for the next fifty or sixty years. I'll give him the mike now and you'll see what I mean. This apple didn't fall far from the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted prepares to speak. A little nervous from the spotligh but hell, he's a man now. Uncle Billy gives him a reassur look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Don't forget to tell them all your qualifications.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ted Nelson. I guess you already know that part. (proud of himself) For two years I've been the editor of the high school paper in Xenia, Ohio. I've won some awards, made a difference. I've always had journalism in my soul. Now I know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at Uncle Billy, who urges him to tell more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell me I've got my father's taste in women and cars.  (winking) The faster, the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHUCKLES from the crowd. Uncle Billy gives him a "thumb's sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm really looking forward to the challenge of bringing "Heaven" magazine into the 21st century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of waxing her bikini line, Christy jumps up down excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked me to the prom! ME! We're practically engaged!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie watches TV. Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reinvented himself into a dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin watches TV. Simmering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even have your high school diploma yet, Mr. Nelson. I'm still the boss of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's parents and little Jimmy stare in amazement at thei old-fashioned console RCA.  A geeky high school picture o Ted appears on screen, as a REPORTER babbles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big question now remains: Will success spoil Ted Nelson, the straight-A journalism student from Xenia, Ohio, whose life was transformed overnight when he found out he was rich, powerful, and certainly the most eligible bachelor in the entire nation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Our Teddy inherited "Heaven?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he was set for book money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy turns to his parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad. Forget about roller blades for my birthday. I'd prefer a DNA test. Can you prove beyond a shadow of a doubt that I am not, for example, a Guccione?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bell CHIMES. Mom and Dad look at each other. Thi can't be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad opens the front door to reveal a delivery man, holding a flashy new bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delivery for Jimmy Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy squeezes past Dad and jumps on the bike as Mom appe in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My goodness, who sent this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from "Heaven," ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (riding around) I love you, Ted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't accept it.  It's much too expensive. Right, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, dumpling. Its very nice of Ted but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, ANOTHER DELIVERY MAN and his HELPER unloa large crate from another truck. They approach Dad and Mom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delivery for Robert Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appears to be tools, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Ted's gone completely overboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad approaches the crate as the Delivery Man opens it to reveal a large scarlet and gray case of tools.  Dad opens of the drawers.  Runs his fingers over the shiny instrume Tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always wanted Craftsman tools. He even got me the limited edition Buckeye colors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, honey. We can't accept this extravagance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another delivery truck arrives.  Then the local news vans Neighbors rush out of their houses. The phone RINGS.  Mom dashes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted wears a cordless headset phone, as if he was born wit it. As he talks, he flexes his muscles in front of a full length mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? Surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is all this? When are you coming home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few tokens of my affection. I'll be back soon, don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is lovely, Ted, but much too expensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom. Believe me. I could buy all that AND the factories they came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom looks up as ANOTHER DELIVERY MAN wheels a washing mac and dryer into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you want them, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, good lord. Are those Neptunes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the best for my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softening) You promise you'll finish school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make you very proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful spring morning.  Cars pull into the school parking lot.  Students mingle in small groups. Making the way into the building.  A group of GUYS look up. Suddenly, a helicopter swooshes through the air, circling school as if to get everyone's attention, then landing on grassy knoll. The helicopter is painted heavenly blue wit pattern of white billowy clouds. The door slides open and out hops Ted. In SLOW-MO. Lookin seriously cool from the tips of his silver toed boots to stylish Persol shades.  Until he takes a second step and stumbles slightly, catching himself from falling face fir into the grass. Charlie is right behind him. Looking great, too, but vagu Mafioso in his efforts to be hip. He turns to the beautif blonde PILOT and plants a big wet kiss for everyone to se Ted and Charlie strut towards the school as Principal Mer bursts through the front doors, shouting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot land a helicopter in my school yard! Get that blasted thing out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted raises his hand.  The chopper rises as if on cue.  Without a word, Ted and Charlie pass the ruffled Principa Merkin and strut toward the entrance. Classmates surround Ted.  Congratulating him.  Everyone wanting to be Ted's n best friend.  Julie walks up to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gives, Don Corleone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smug) We reinvented ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Hushpuppies don't make a new man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've obviously never had your dogs nestled in thousand dollar Italian loafers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That explains the emptiness that haunts me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jealousy is so unattractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted makes eye contact with Julie. Winking like he's Don J She just stares at him, blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second only to unfettered arrogance and the inability to see the irony therein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's baffled by that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna see my hickey from Miss December?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin paces dramatically...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you, Ted. You know that. I liked you before you were filthy rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Principal Merkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be blunt. I know you can take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I'll brace myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, you are the best editor this school paper ever had. You don't need to be pandering flesh. It's nonsense. It's beneath you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I ought to just tell them thanks but no thanks? I don't want your silly billion dollar empire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good start, yes. A very good start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? This magazine is my dream. It's every red-blooded, heterosexual male's dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never figured you for a pimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever even looked at "Heaven?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of sick question is that?  I'll be watching you, young man. Your money and power mean nothing here. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you won't be wanting that Rolex I sent you, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin opens his desk drawer sheepishly. Caress the watch. It kills him to return it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, I won't. Thank you. For reminding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flurry of activity. Ted on his cell phone. Julie types furiously. Taking her job very seriously. Christy Malone props one leg against the wall. Demonstrating those contortionist warm-up moves that drove Ted mad with desir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great jacket, Teddy Bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hanging up phone) Yeah? You like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes your shoulders look so big and broad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few billion bucks and suddenly he's Cro-Magnon Man of the Year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so nice to have FRIENDS like you, Christy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy pouts. Wishing she never said the "F" word. Julie snickers. Ted takes Julie's arm and guides her to a priva spot in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, William Randolph? Your balls need scratching?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your article sucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what sense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the sense that there is no "hidden agenda" behind a bake sale that raised five hundred dollars for seeing eye dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah ha! It was so well hidden, you didn't even know it was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Julie. Don't screw up. You have some real talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because someone died and made you king of the publishing world doesn't mean you're even one ounce smarter than you were a week ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still better than you. Nothing changed except the decimal point in your savings account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not ENTIRELY true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie snaps her fingers, as if trying to remember...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. You're probably not a virgin anymore. But as far as being a hack, that much is status quo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted fumes. She really knows how to push his buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me? I'm trying to be fair. But I can't keep you on staff if you turn every PTA meeting into an Agent Orange cover up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll write about YOU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Local boy inherits more money than god." Call me crazy, but I smell human interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loving this) Really? You wanna write about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A world class CHEF and his SOUS CHEF serve the Nelson's a filet mignon dinner. Mom, Dad, Jimmy, Ted, and Julie, sit the table. Set with the finest china. The most elegant linens. A fresh floral arrangement. The best of everythin Everyone waits for Mom as she takes her first bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness...it's delicious. I've never tasted anything so tender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of them dig in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats the heck out of meatloaf. (off Mom's look) Although your meatloaf is second to none, love muffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy's eyes widen as he chews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad. My trembling taste buds have just been assailed by the bittersweet knowledge of all they've been missing these past nine years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chef turns to Julie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense, Wolfgang Puck, but dead flesh is dead flesh. This just happens to be better than most dead flesh on the planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally, the Chef waits for Ted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely...heavenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chef wipes a bead of sweat from his brow. Approval, a last, from the only opinion that mattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you, sir. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted has bettered our lives to the point where I can no longer see myself as "the old Jimmy" I was but a day or two past. You may all call me James. From this moment forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, some gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're grateful, Ted. It's not that. Those Craftsman tools...they're a dream come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Dad and I were raised with a certain work ethic, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie listens closely, admiring Ted's parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't start living like we're the Rockerfellers or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad. The Rockerfellers are paupers compared to my favorite brother, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to work another day in your lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how would we pay our bills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just barely have enough for your college tuition, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's frustration mounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you get it? In one day I earn more interest than the store's entire annual revenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're free.  You can do anything you ever wanted to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like take that trip to Buckingham Palace. Go deep sea fishing in the Gulf of Mexico. Now's your chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But those are our dreams, son. We have to make them come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider me your fairy godfather, except without the fairy part. No more mealy apples and bruised bananas, ever, for the rest of your lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who would run the store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the store. Think big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad looks at Mom. Forget the store. That stings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, we put a lot of love in our business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wanted you and Jimmy to have it someday. Something real and honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We love our lives just the way they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappointed, disgusted, Ted looks to Julie for support. Tears fill her eyes. Mom and Dad moved her. Ted shrugs an digs into his food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavenly blue jet with billowy white clouds soars throu the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond first class; the ultimate in posh. Charlie sweet-t a sexy FLIGHT ATTENDANT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Charlie. I'm a photographer for "Heaven" magazine. And a very cunning linguist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Flight Attendant pulls him toward the washroom, quick Julie interviews Ted, complete with tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to admit, I always felt... different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different how? Different like a dwarf at a basketball game? Or different like a lesbian in pumps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get the distinction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could everybody else tell you were different, or were you the only one who knew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt limited. I felt confined. I felt like I was suffocating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. So more like a tight rope walker who secretly wants to be a trapeze artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another FLIGHT ATTENDANT approaches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm peanuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. I prefer my penis at room temperature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said peanuts, you cretin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie raises her eyebrows. Taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't write that part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this an gritty exposй or a candy ass press release?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write what you want. Just try not to make it so obvious that you're crazy about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
