dialogues.text: (amused) Life must be peachy on Planet Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny you should say "peachy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did my homework. Your grandfather was a peach farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My adoptive grandfather. Who knows what my biological grandfather did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Undoubtedly an aristocratic bartender of some sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted loves her spunk. And the chemistry between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Considering this is your first time on a private jet, on which you are interviewing the world's most eligible bachelor,  you are extremely cavalier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet there are lots and lots of mirrors on Planet Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? You're impertinent, rude, sarcastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is not my first time on a private jet, so quit acting like I'm Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little respect would be nice, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie snickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money can't buy respect, Ted. Saying what you mean. Meaning what you say. Being an honorable person. That's how you earn respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted waits for his appearance on "The Tonight Show."  Ging smooths out the imaginary creases in Ted's Armani jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great jacket, Teddy. It makes your shoulders look so big and broad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie rolls her eyes. Here we go again.  Uncle Billy and Helen look on approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do look smashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Positively dashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharp as a mashed potato sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted fake-guffaws. Charlie is quickly distracted by the re tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh wow, look...they've even got baby gherkins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an idea! I'll be right back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she dashes out the door.  Ted leans towards Julie, wh quietly observes everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? What do you think of her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so twitterpated you don't even see the miner's hat and the pickax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're implying she's, what, a gold digger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie shrugs. Isn't it obvious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's right. Jealousy is so unattractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second only to unbridled, narcissistic conceit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whining) Why can't you be nice to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got enough people kissing your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginger returns with a rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go, cutie patootie. Rich guys always wear flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie gives Ted a look. See what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jay Leno seems charmed.  Ted behaves as if he does this e day. The rose from Ginger is pinned to his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are the hometown folks treating you, back in Xenia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Jay. They've been exceptionally supportive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they hitting you up for donations? Asking you to sponsor the local quilting bee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audience LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no stranger to the notion of philanthropy. Andrew Carnegie has long been one of my idols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the future? You planning to rock the boat at all? Stir things up in "Heaven?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's so smooth. We know it's still HIM under all that Armani, but it sure does make him LOOK different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matter of fact, Jay, my uncle and I are planning to rethink the magazine. To expand the traditional western notions of "beauty."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see, so you'd be open to little ladies from Pasadena, who want to show you their knickers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matter of fact, Jay, I'm planning a pictorial focusing on the women of my hometown, "The Girls of Xenia." Just to show my appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: OFF IN THE WINGS
dialogues.text: Julie looks thoroughly disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Girls of Xenia? Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're talking. What did Andrew Carnegie ever do? Open a couple of libraries? BOR-ING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Cocker Spaniel, POOCHIE, sits under a breakfast table, holding a newspaper in his snout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poochie?  Where's my poochie? Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. MERKIN, dressed in a bathrobe and curlers, prepares breakfast.  Their beautiful college-aged daughter, JUDY, cereal at the table, while flipping through a glamour magazine. Principal Merkin enters. Ready for work. Wife a daughter don't even look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my Poochie in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin pretends to look for the dog in the cupboard. This is obviously a daily ritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she in here?  No.  Where on earth could she be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks under the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's my Poochie!  There's my girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog leaps into his arms.  Principal Merkin grabs the paper as Poochie starts to lick his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poochie loves Daddy, doesn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast is getting cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No dogs at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin places the dog on the ground, takes a se and bites into a breakfast sausage.  He opens the paper a is confronted by a full page ad.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER AD
dialogues.text: "GIRLS OF XENIA, GO STRAIGHT TO HEAVEN!"  Details follow. How, when, where to apply.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRINCIPAL MERKIN
dialogues.text: Who chokes on his sausage. Clutches his throat. Signaling his wife and daughter. "Help me!" Judy looks up, grossed Mrs. Merkin attempts the Heimlich Maneuver. Rather ineptl Principal Merkin turns red, blue, purple. Finally the pie of sausage flies out of his mouth, past Judy. Poochie cat it in mid-flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) Thatta girl.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin drives to work, humming along to Liza Minelli's "New York, New York." The song comes to an end a radio spot begins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times have people told you, "Jeepers, you look swell naked!" Well now's your chance to go straight to "Heaven!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin tries to change the station. But the ad seems to be on every station...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on down for "The Girls of Xenia" pictorial. Let's show the nation our cows aren't the only ones with great udders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students hover at the bulletin board, reading a poster advertising the "Heaven" auditions.  Principal Merkin pus through the crowd and tears the poster off the board.  Completely incensed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of Xenia CITIZENS have gathered for this meeting Principal Merkin stands in front of the five members of t city council who sit at a U-shaped table.  He holds up "Heaven" magazine. Preaching with an evangelical passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This, my friends, this is not "Heaven." This flesh rag is a one way ticket to hell! We must voice our outrage! To remain passive in the eye of the devil is like inviting him to a pot luck in your own backyard and asking him to bring the three-bean salad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His supporters murmur agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the sake of this community, and its impressionable young minds, I propose this publication be banned from our city!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His POSSE of supporters APPLAUD. His opponents GROAN. Ted slouches nearby.  A lawyer next to him.  The MAYOR bangs gavel and the commotion settles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for that long-winded but impassioned speech, Mr. Merkin. I hope you can cut to the chase, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin takes his seat. Ted rises. Playing the b shot lawyer. Julie sits in the crowd, taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect to Merk, he doesn't have to read my magazine. But he has no right to stop others. (to Principal Merkin) Ever hear of the First Amendment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising; an outburst) We cannot afford free speech if it excises the moral fiber of this community!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that were true, this would be one seriously constipated town. Most guys in Xenia have been looking at naked girls in "Heaven" since they were old enough to figure out their dads hide it under the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit of an UPROAR from the crowd. WOMEN eye their HUSBAN suspiciously. Julie makes a point...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it true, Principal Merkin, that you only care now because "Heaven" is suddenly too close to home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed it is, Miss Conroy! I make no bones about it! "Heaven" has gone too far!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. NEEDLEMAN, another angry man from Principal Merkin's posse, jumps on the bandwagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin is right! We can't let "Heaven" violate our own daughters, wives, sisters, mothers, girlfriends, aunts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen motions to Ted. He quickly locates a page in the re she prepared for him. He handles this like a pro...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to name names, Mr. Needleman, or cause any undue embarrassment. But many members of this community have been loyal "Heaven" readers for the better part of the last two decades. Not to mention certain charter subscribers who have developed a voracious appetite for our video library as well. I don't suppose, "Courtney Leaves The Convent" rings a bell to anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Needleman dissolves into his seat. Half the men in th audience seem to evaporate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Nelson, you are Beelzebub's henchman! You are single-handedly destroying the integrity of our community, and I will not have it!  I'll gather signatures. I'll petition the courts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) You do what you have to do, Dick. But if there's a man among us who doesn't like to steal a look at some pretty titty once in a while, let him cast the first stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is suddenly SILENT. Principal Merkin gives the M a hard look.  Merkin's face contorts in SLOW MO as he proclaims...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I. AM. THAT. MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding a stack of flyers, Charlie chats with Judy, Merki college-aged daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're like a centerfold waiting to happen. And let me assure you, I have some serious pull with the publisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy smiles fetchingly. Stashing Charlie's "Heaven" flyer her backpack. Her father suddenly appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an adult. I can do whatever I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My roof, my rules, young lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs her arm while knocking the stack of flyers out o Charlie's hands.  As Principal Merkin drags her away, Jud smiles back at Charlie.  He winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send us a picture, sugar.  We'll get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stack of flyers FLOATS over the railing and onto the ground floor, just as a group of LOVELY YOUNG WOMEN enter the building lobby. They excitedly reach for the flyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of BEAUTIFUL WOMEN - all shapes and sizes - snakes around the block and into a doorway.  The women are dress to impress, in very skimpy clothing. Ted pulls up in his convertible Ferrari. The women shout greetings as Ted hea for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Ted as he dashes up the stairs, along the line women, towards an office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (greeting the women) Hello there...Looking great...Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks frazzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late, bro!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Ginger got a little, you know, enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never believe who's in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better not be my Aunt Trudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG WOMAN sits with her back to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you waiting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman turns towards Ted, revealing herself to be Chri Malone.  Ted is momentarily stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Teddy Bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy?  You want to be in "Heaven?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I turned eighteen over spring break. I'm eligible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted doesn't know what to say. Charlie's equally stunned.  Hell, it seems, has frozen over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I've just been hit by a Mack truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a refrigerated cargo bed full of sirloin tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Highly modified since the last time we saw it. A large fl screen hangs on the wall.   A high tech computer system f video conferences dominates the room.  Ted speaks with Un Billy and Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far, so good. Some of them have real Angel potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? So I'm doing OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're impressed but not surprised, Ted. You have your father's impeccable judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad passes the partially open door. Overhearing. He stops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father must've been amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in a league of his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Ted feels his dad's presence, behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. You need me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding a list) Your mom said you've been ignoring your chores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted takes the list.  Gives it a cursory glance. Nods to h dad, as if dismissing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem, consider it done. (to Uncle Billy) I had this idea of shooting on location. Outdoors, you know? Maybe at some famous Xenia landmarks.  You think that would be a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll send you the release forms, Ted. Our staffers will help in any way they can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the Titan of Tushies, the General of Jism.  Don't you forget it, Ted-baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted laughs. Completely ignoring his dad. Who backs out of room. Unnoticed. Neglected. Hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom drives up to the house.  She stares, aghast. There are tall, beautiful, ANGELS everywhere.  One cuts t grass.  Another pulls weeds. Two others on the roof, clea gutters. Still others wash the car...with Jimmy handling the water hose. Drenching the women, more than the car. Shrieks and giggles all around. Neighbors gawk. Ted's dad guiltily enjoys the view, but quickly rushes to wife. She gets out of her car and steadies herself on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stands on an ottoman as a TAILOR fits him for a prom tuxedo. He towers over his parents who try to talk to him feel for them. They've lost control of their kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to understand. This was a big shock, for all of us. One minute you're our little boy, of whom we could not be more proud. The next minute you're the owner of this whole pornographic empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that doesn't make you the boss of everything, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see how your self involvement and lack of humility are affecting the whole family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks down at them, literally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paid off the mortgage! I ordered that Winnebago you always wanted! Now you're ashamed of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ordered a Winnebago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom gives Dad a look. Stick to the script. Don't be swaye presents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not ashamed of you, Teddy. We don't approve of the magazine or the models or the so-called "flesh parties" you attend. But we can get past all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We miss you. We miss our son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We miss our family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised I'd finish high school and that's what I'm doing. What more do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad glances at Mom, hesitant.  She nods, giving him the courage to continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think you should give up the magazine. Sell it. Let someone else run it. Whatever it takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want you to go to college, find a career you love, marry a nice girl from a nice family, and live happily ever after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THAT is your dream, not mine. My dream is so far beyond anything YOU PEOPLE could even imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your tone, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just admit what this is really all about? I'm not your real kid and you can't control me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad look stricken. Ted doesn't know when to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder I was so bored. No wonder I hated this one-horse cow town. I come from talented people who took chances and dared to imagine a life without limits! I was never meant to be raised by...GROCERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted storms away, unintentionally CRASHING into a TREASURE FAMILY PHOTO on the end table. The frame shatters into smithereens. Breaking Mom and Dad's hearts. STUNNED SILEN hangs heavy in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prom night.  Couples slow dance to a Marilyn Manson clone singing a rock version of "Precious and Few." Principal Merkin watches on the sidelines.  Surprisingly calm. Suspiciously happy. Ted caresses Ginger's bare back as they dance together. H head nestled against her breasts. Not a care in the world He spots Charlie on the dance floor. Making out with one his dates, the IDENTICAL TAYLOR TRIPLETS, while the other patiently wait their turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy? I was thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After graduation...maybe we could go away together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE notice Christy Malone dancing with her FOOTBALL CAPTAI DATE. The perfect male specimen. Christy gives Ted a disappointed, longing gaze. But he's oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet St. Tropez in July would be paradise. For a honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a FLASH blinds them. It's Julie Conroy, doing he job.  Following her subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) You could have warned us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops, sorry. Warning: You've got lipstick on your teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie flashes the camera again. Capturing Ginger's panick expression. We notice that Julie looks alluring in a deep purple strapless gown. Not so glamorous as Ginger, but fa more appealing and natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow...you clean up nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your eyeballs back in your head, William Randolph. I'm on assignment. A girl has to fit in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginger seems testy and jealous. Her true colors emerging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy, I thought we were having a moment here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the music dies.  Everyone turns to the stage whe Principal Merkin stands proudly. Holding a power cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for interrupting the festivities, but I have some good news. I've been reviewing the rules and regulations set forth by the superintendent of schools. And it seems quite clear... (reading from manual) "Minors may not be accompanied to school functions by adults unless they are their parents or legal guardians."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spotlight suddenly finds Ted and Charlie's beautiful da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, ladies. Prom's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd boos, hisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly, Merk. It's like you were never seventeen and the head of a media empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rules are rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, it's our only senior prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaf ears, Mr. Nelson. I answer to a higher power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie steps in like a hostage negotiator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the deal, Merk.  Forget the "rules and regulations" malarkey and we'll give you seven minutes in heaven with the Taylor Triplets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out! Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted realizes his high school reputation is at stake. He s up on stage. Approaches Principal Merkin. Takes out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your price, Merk? How much will it cost to make you go bye bye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd CHEERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crossing the line, Mr. Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A statue in front of city hall, dedicated to Principal Dick Merkin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm warning you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new pediatric wing at the hospital? A presidential campaign? Name it. Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin trembles from the sheer temptation of it Yet he could never succumb in front of so many witnesses. has to maintain his dignity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it! You're out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From nowhere, a flock of beefy SECURITY GUARDS emerge to remove Ted & Co.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Mr. Nelson.  Have a pleasant evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marilyn Manson clone is rapidly whisked away, and replaced by six GEEZERS in powder blue tuxedoes. As Security Guards carry them away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted! Do something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (restrained) What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is humiliating. We're being ejected from a prom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang in there, I'll think of something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they reach the doors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess...I don't know...I guess we should leave if we're not wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you, bro. We're Angus men in a ground round town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what I get for playing den mother in "Romper Room." Take me to the airport, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just hitch a ride on the horse you rode in on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ginger storms away in an angry huff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after her) Don't forget your broom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted experiences a moment of loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I loved her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicks are like buses. If you miss one, don't sweat it. There's another coming 'round the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Taylor Triplets bats her lashes at Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to Ted) Take your pick. They're IDENTICAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted grins broadly. He turns and SHOUTS to his classmates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody, listen up! This prom sucks!  Let's party at my place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Responses are mixed. Some cheer, some are undecided. Unti the new band starts playing, "Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round t Old Oak Tree." And EVERYONE RUSHES for the exit, followin Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A muzak version of "Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Old Oak Tree," continues.  A PIZZA DELIVERY GUY watches the numbe rise to the penthouse.  Suddenly the doors open to reveal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four penthouse suites have been rented by Ted.  It's party central. Very wild.  Quickly growing out of control Kids dance, play drinking games, Spin the Bottle, and generally trash the place. The pizza delivery guy wheels a dolly with a huge stack o pizzas into the party, only to be attacked by the prom-go like starving beasts. Grabbing the pizzas.  Devouring the hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: TED'S LUXURIOUS HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: Ted, Charlie, the Taylor Triplets and several buddies lou around, drunkenly watching THE HOME SHOPPING CHANNEL on T big screen TV.  A tacky CERAMIC GNOME rotates on the scre Ted swigs Dom Perignon straight from the bottle. He shout orders into his cell phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yes, all hundred and seventeen of 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, leave one. Somebody's grandmother might want one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while you're at it, I'll take ten dozen of those puppies with the springy heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love those springy head puppies!

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Ted looks up as the elevator doors open.  Principal Merki has arrived. Ted confronts him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kicked us off your turf, Merk.  Don't rain on our parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Nelson, you disappoint me. First you break our school board rules. Then you break the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What law, Merk? Having fun? Letting down our hair on prom night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our state has a zero tolerance policy for underage drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called the cops on us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alcohol does horrible things to a developing young mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the whole XENIA POLICE FORCE appears, in full ri gear.  The party's over.  Everyone runs for the stairs. gives Principal Merkin a spiteful look and joins the mass exodus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunken teenagers pour out of the building.  Dashing for their cars and limos.  Ted's among them.  Suddenly he's c off by a Harley that stops right in front of him.  It's Julie.  Still in her purple strapless prom dress. With a black motorcycle jacket over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a lift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted jumps on, wrapping his arms around her waist. Julie t off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie maneuvers the nighttime streets of Xenia, taking of down a country road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the best hiding place in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we understand. Julie's family comes from major bucks. yard is massive. And resting in a sprawling oak tree is t best hiding place in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cozy oasis. Books everywhere.  A whole series of flashlights hang upside down like lanterns. Giving the tr house a warm glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe your dad built this for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't. He had it built.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not "whatever."  It's two different things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cared enough to want you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He phoned it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it makes sense, the whole neo Bohemian, down with hypocrisy, fight the power crap. You're a poor little rich girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ozone must be fully depleted on Planet Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think my dad would have been like that if I knew him? You think he would have bought me a stadium, instead of teaching me how to play ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dad taught you everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A father is nothing but sperm, Ted. It takes a real man to be a dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all so complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's incredibly simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I'm being drawn and quartered. Like every part of me is being pushed and pulled and tugged in a different direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually you'll let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll see who's really holding on to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even when you infuriate me, I still want to kiss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you never do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we were a team, we could do anything. I mean, anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie's eyes narrow. She should have known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut to the chase, William Randolph.  Your audience is way ahead of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a word: MERK. EXPOSED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's two words. And I'm out of the "exposed" business, remember? I need to graduate. Besides, Merk's a boy scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's gotta be something. We have to dig deeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forget, I dislike YOU at least as much as him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shut down your paper!  You're stuck writing articles about swap meets and raffles and PTA brunches!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good journalist can take lemons and make lemonade. I'm honing my craft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you won't mind covering that watermelon seed spitting contest next week...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed in a old fashioned barber costume, complete with handle bar mustache, Principal Merkin sings as part of a BARBER SHOP QUARTET. The senior citizens clap enthusiastically. Ted and Julie peek through a crack in the doorway. Disappointment on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin pours soup into the bowl of a shabbily dressed HOMELESS MAN. Julie shoots Ted an "I told you so" look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin supervises a crew of kindergarten CHILDR cleaning up the roadside litter. Julie and Ted watch from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what I mean. He's squeaky clean. He makes Gandhi look like a war monger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted steels himself. Somehow, they'll get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the golden light of sunset, MOLLY, a stunning "Xenia Girl," stands on the stairs that curve up around a huge w tower that overlooks the city.  Her loose spring dress billows in the wind. Held on by only one button. Exposing quick glimpses that she isn't wearing a bra.  An ASSISTANT holds a portable strobe, attached to a reflector.  Charlie shoots with his Nikon.  Motor drive whirling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a great idea.  Let's lose the last button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly grins. Then unbuttons. We hear a round of "oohs" fr below.  Ted glances down, where... Hundreds of binoculars, cameras, and camcorders are poise the scene.  Men of all ages are milling around, gawking, focusing their long lenses.  Women are conspicuously abse Except for the gaggle of hardcore FEMINISTS with their placards, denouncing "Heaven." One Feminist approaches the Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city tower belongs to the city, not to some pornographer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The library also belongs to the city.  And guess what?  It's going to have a new Ted Nelson wing with  three thousand children's books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Feminist tries to respond, but a helicopter swoops overhead, drowning out her words. The helicopter rises to level of the photo shoot where the door slides open.  And just when we think it must have been hired by some hard c fans who wanted a closer look, we find Principal Merkin frowning as he barks through a bullhorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed, young lady!  Your body is a sacred temple!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly flashes him. Principal Merkin averts his eyes.  Mis the sight of Molly's dress being blown off her body by th chopper's prop wash.  The spectators below APPLAUD.  They watch in amazement as her dress floats down to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young lady, I will pray for god's mercy upon your soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother, Merk! I'm already going to "Heaven!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) Get them together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes lighting up) Brilliant!  Molly, give me all you've got.  For Merk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molly gets the idea.  She poses provocatively towards Principal Merkin, who suddenly realizes he's in a compromising position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that, stop that this instant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Molly pulls off her panties and flings them at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy chortles, his image glowing on a large flat screen monitor that hangs on the wall.  Ted leans back in chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw anybody turn so many shades of red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to see the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was incredible. The light, the crowd, everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy grins proudly at Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such enthusiasm. Have I told you lately how proud I am of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously? I'm doing all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're taking this bull of an empire by the horns, but you're still keeping your small town values. You're not letting all this "stuff" spoil you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted knows it's not true. He looks guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe it all to you. Without your help I'd be lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I knew you years ago, when my brother was alive. I wish he never gave you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, like my Grandpa used to say...you can't change your Christmas past, but you sure can exchange your Christmas presents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy forces a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come to town this weekend? We could play some golf, chase some skirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted smiles at the appealing offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to, but I really need to crack the books.  Final exams are coming up and I've been slacking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I should work, too. Our first issue together is almost ready to print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Uncle Billy. Thanks for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a great kid. Don't you forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, he's gone. The room is completely silent. And is completely alone. UNTIL the doorbell CHIMES.

dialogues.speaker: TED'S LUXURIOUS HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: Ted opens the door. It's Jimmy, with his shiny new bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can call me Jimmy again. Sheryl Petersen said James sounds too pretentious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheryl Petersen is, what, nine years old, what does she know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knew exactly where you were staying, which you neglected to tell me, your own brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really late...do your parents know where you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad think I'm tucked safely in bed and that's all they need to know. Will this discussion be continuing in the hallway, or somewhere slightly more inviting?

dialogues.speaker: TED'S LUXURIOUS HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: Jimmy seems impressed by the opulence. He takes off his b helmet, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressive. This is bigger than our whole house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most places are, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say money can't buy happiness but this is a reasonably good facsimile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what brings you here at his hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My new bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to ask permission to take custody of your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better view, more spacious, new carpet. It's a no-brainer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not up to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad said it's yours. They seem to think you're coming home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have it, then. I'm not going back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy whips out a piece of paper from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could just sign right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want it in writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a formality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted signs. Jimmy squirrels away the paper, excitedly. Sta to zip up his wind breaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it? I mean, you don't want to order room service or anything? We could play games and watch movies and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Mom and Dad discover I'm gone and I'll be doing hard time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aside from the fact that Mom's eyes are nearly swollen shut from crying and Dad spends all his time under the car trying to fix stuff that isn't broken, things couldn't be better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss them, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't come back. That is, you can, but your things will be in the room you currently think of as mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a peach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny you should say that. My Grandfather was a peach farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. For the first time, that really smarts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was my Grandfather, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant biologically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a crappy thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Ted. I'm cool with everything. You've long been dissatisfied with our mediocre little town. You've always had an itch for the good life. I'm happy for you. This couldn't happen to a nicer guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But just for the record, my Mom is a kick-ass schoolteacher and my Dad is the best damn auto mechanic this side of the Himalayas. You seem to have forgotten they opened Nelson's FAMILY Market so they could build something permanent, a legacy, for us. Their kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever look down on them again and call them "grocers" like it's a dirty word, and you'll be sucking your filet mignon through a straw for six to eight weeks. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's stunned. Talk about tough love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud and clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the phone rings. Ted sheepishly explains...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's probably my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? Where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the move?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an anonymous tip and an address in Cincinnati.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do it.

dialogues.speaker: TED'S LUXURIOUS HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: Ted hangs up the phone.  Looks around.  Jimmy's gone. But SHINY NEW BIKE is left behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much of a place. A middle-aged TORCH SINGER croons "M ROMANCE."  Ted and Julie find their way to corner table. Keeping an eye out for Principal Merkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. This place seems pretty tame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expected whips, chains, Merk being cattle-prodded by some dominatrix in a leather hood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least it's not another 4-H meeting or a Big Brother barbecue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their heads are very close together. A conspiratorial tкt tкte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at us. It's one o'clock in the morning, on a school night. We're in a smoky nightclub, hoping to catch our principal with some big city tart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trembling with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That has more to do with your proximity to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) My desire betrays me, like goosebumps on my flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a bit of a goosebump fetish. Not many people know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured you for more of a hairy armpit guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoes, if you want to know the truth. Shoes are my thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing them?  Or humping them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fantasy is a totally naked woman, wearing nothing but a Timex and suede clogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's refreshingly deviant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very aural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds, voices, music, humming. All of it can turn me on, or off, like a switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning a deep voice) I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a Portuguese boyfriend who could read the phone book and melt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jealous) A Portuguese boyfriend. Sounds very "Cosmo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live and learn. I realized the most important thing to me, above all, is trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turned out to be a scoundrel, eh?  I saw that one coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lose trust in someone and it's over, done, gone, forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, the TORCH SINGER begins crooning "PEOPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you trust me, Julie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust is something you earn, over time. You don't just inherit it overnight like a gazillion dollar empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted leans even closer. Looking into her eyes. Using his voice. Being as aurally seductive as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie, I'll tell you something that is the god's honest truth. I've seen a lot of really beautiful girls. I mean a lot. But none of them make me feel like you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's hard to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But absolutely true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted moves closer.  Julie doesn't move away.  The SINGER s to be performing just for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..."A feeling deep in your soul/Says you were half, now you're whole..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Ted and Julie are about to kiss, Julie's eyes wid She grabs Ted's hand. Simultaneously, they turn towards T SINGER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OH. MY. GOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Mother Lode!  That's not just any middle-aged to singer. That's Principal Merkin.  Dressed in drag as Barb Streisand. And doing a mighty fine job of it. Ted pulls out his camera and fires away. Blinded by the s lights, Principal Merkin sings and vogues glamorously. He no idea his secret is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Julie rush down the street in the rain, giggling, totally euphoric. They stop to catch their breath. Their clothes are drenched, but they couldn't care less. In no they've got their arms wrapped around one another, kissin and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just found the ULTIMATE centerfold for "The Girls of Xenia!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Julie sobers, pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be honest with you, Ted. I really despise "The Girls of Xenia."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, their small town mentality can be maddening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean your pictorial. It bothers me, profoundly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw Julie, it's my job. It's like being a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie eyes him skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me you don't get aroused by a roomful of naked breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen one naked breast, you've seem them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which explains the continued success of "Heaven" for how many decades?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're quick. I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're working with chimps here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, I made a commitment. I said I'd do it and I have to keep my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping your word is something I can actually respect, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted closes the back of his camera. Takes a deep breath. A forces a confident smile. He then peers into the...

dialogues.speaker: SHOWER
dialogues.text: Where Christy Malone limbers up.  Stretching her leg agai the wall. Wearing her sexy cheerleader uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd be nervous, but you sure know how to make a girl feel relaxed, Teddy Bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do? I mean, yeah, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to admit, I am so totally turned on. We should do it. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know...take the pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy does her warm-up contortionist poses for Ted.  Clothes still on.  As reflectors bounce strobes into the shower area. Years of being a merciless tease, paying off right here a now. Christy knows how to make love to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember the first time you walked into Mrs. Temple's class in 2nd grade. Blue gingham dress. Blond ponytail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which you pulled, hard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was code for "I like you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna unzip me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted slowly unzips Christy's top, catching a glimpse of he long, sensuous back. She resumes posing. Flashing a bare shoulder.  A coy look. She doesn't need direction. She's natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember dress up day?  You and Charlie lifting skirts during recess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss those days, when schoolyard sexual harassment was without consequence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things change. Now I'm taking off my clothes...all by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christy slips off her cheerleader top. Lowers her skirt. Flings it aside. She's wearing only panties the size of a Band-aid. Ted is mute. Staring at her perfect body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have changed since second grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect me to think at a time like this? There isn't a drop of blood in my brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Teddy Bear, you're funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted steps out of the shower.  Out of Christy's sight, he squirms in his jeans. Trying to hide his enthusiasm. MUSIC suddenly seems to come from nowhere. Nine Inch Nail "I Want to Fuck You Like An Animal."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) God help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted steps back into the shower.  Christy rubs an ice cube her left nipple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard they do this on photo shoots.  Wanna to do the other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tosses him the ice cube. He fumbles. It lands on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing just fine, Christy. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm ready when you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks through the lens. We can see him trembling.  Mu blasts as Ted's camera burns through film.  They're both getting into it.  Water pulsating over her body. Steam rising.  Christy begins lathering her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was always too shy to admit how much I liked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I was hamburger. You were porterhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe on the outside. But inside, deep down, I've always been dripping with special sauces.  (she smiles, sexily) Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he hungry. He's been working up this appetite for ten years. He can barely contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you are so hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you better get in the water, before you get burned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted calls her bluff. He sets aside his camera. Walks righ into the water. Through the steam.  Toward Christy. She w a leg around him, sucking face, wanting more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me, finally. This will be so fantastic, Teddy Bear. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Ted stops. Remembering what Julie said about tru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Christy. I've been crazy about you forever, and this is definitely a page right out of my palm pilot, but I just can't go through with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away, but Christy presses her bare body against back.  Wrapping her hands around his waist. Caressing his chest, his stomach...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can. You're only human. It's not like you're made of steel. (she lowers her hand) Or ARE you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Christy locked in a steamy embrace. Rolling on th floor. Hands, arms, lips, tongues, all in motion. As the shower drenches them. Suddenly, they roll into a pair of legs.  Both look up. steam clears to reveal Julie. Arms crossed. Hurt, but not surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't wait for an explanation. Christy covers herse Ted chases after Julie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, Julie, wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie dashes out of the girls' locker room, passing a JANITOR.  Ted follows, dripping water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Ted. She pushed right past me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after Julie) At least let me explain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie darts into the girls' restroom.  Ted stops at the d Then realizes there is no one else around.  He heads insi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie's too proud to let him see her cry. But we can tell she's upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away, Ted. Just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted corners her near a row of sinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please believe me. It was just a kiss for old time's sake. I've had a stupid crush on her since I was seven, but I never got closer to her than four feet and then there she was right in front of me, completely naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie looks at him, pensively. She unzips the back of her summery dress. And lets it fall to the floor. She's completely naked and absolutely gorgeous. Ted gasps. He's been around dozens of naked women by now, this one he can't just gawk at. This one he really cares about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being naked is no big deal. It has nothing to do with emotion, nothing to do with love. You can be around all the naked girls you want and you won't be even one step closer to anything meaningful in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts on her dress, gracefully. As if nothing happened

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that? You don't know me even one ounce better than you did before. You and your stupid  magazine. I liked you better when you were sweet and kind and human, like the rest of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, Ted's cell phone rings. Julie walks away, leaving Ted completely alone. He answers, lifelessly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a huge problem with the magazine, Ted-baby. Our readers hate it. HATE IT. We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted walks down the hallway.  Three JOCKS look through the issue of "Heaven." Laughing.  They taunt Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a great sense of humor. I love the three hundred pound Eskimo chick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like Eskimo pie, Teddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the African chick with the big lip. You could stash a lot of weed in there. Maybe even a six pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's mortified, depressed. Charlie appears next to him w "Heaven" in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy stinkers, what were you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wanted to challenge the notions of classic beauty. We wanted to showcase women throughout the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time, make sure you put a barf bag in the centerfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin approaches. Also holding "Heaven" in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, I realize I owe you an apology. You're destroying "Heaven" much faster from the inside than I ever could from the outside. Good job, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted could not feel worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, Uncle Billy, and Helen. Meeting with the HEADS OF VARIOUS DEPARTMENTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our advertisers are wigging out. Half of them are threatening to pull their ads for next month. The other half already did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nothing more than beginner's folly. Tell everyone to lighten up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little more serious than that, Bill. The stockholders have requested a meeting. They want our guarantee that this will never happen again. (the words pain her) Some of them are even calling for Ted's resignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, the girls of Xenia are gorgeous, you'll see. Next month we'll be back to normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another disaster like this could sink us. We've got thousands of subscribers requesting refunds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid came up with something that sounded good on paper. Who knew our readers wouldn't dig it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted bristles. THE KID?  The kid came up with something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried to warn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes young people need to make their own mistakes. That's how they learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted can see that Uncle Billy's playing this out different than he imagined. Giving Ted all the "credit."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly; to Uncle Billy) It won't happen again. It will never happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sits at his father's desk.  Going through paperwork.  Figures.  Charts. Reports. CEO work.  In the b.g., he hea the PLAYFUL SOUNDS of women.  Which distract him. Ted approaches the window and watches a group of girls splashing and playing in the pool. He looks sad. Helen en behind him.  He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always thought I wanted fame and fortune and beautiful women. But sometimes your dreams come true, and they cause you nothing but grief. I just want to chuck everything and sell the stupid magazine. It's not worth the pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen takes Ted's hand, comfortingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, let me show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen and Ted sit on old trunk. Helen holds a scrapbook i her arms. Explaining to Ted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your parents never wanted to interfere with your life, Ted. They knew your Mom and Dad loved you very much. They knew they did the right thing. But that doesn't mean they didn't watch you and miss you, from afar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean they knew who I was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kept this scrapbook of your life. It meant the world to them.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAPBOOK
dialogues.text: We see baby pictures of Ted, taken through the glass of a nursery. A newspaper photo of Ted playing a donkey in a nativity play. And clippings from Ted's high school newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered about them, for so many years. I wondered if I looked like them, acted like them. I wondered why they gave me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giving you up was the most unselfish thing they ever did. When they founded "Heaven," they wished they could take you back but it was too late. All they could do was build the empire, knowing that someday it would all be yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My legacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your parents would be crushed to think you weren't happy with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not my parents, Helen. My parents are back in Xenia and I hurt them very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the girl I love, she hates "Heaven." If I keep it, she'll never respect me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how can you respect yourself if you don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's parents and Jimmy walk through the front door. They stunned to find a huge 24x36 enlarged family portrait, hanging over the mantle. It's the same picture Ted broke his childish tantrum. Mom and Dad are moved. Even more so when they see Ted. Waiting for them on the couch.  Ted ri Misty eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything I am is because of you. Can you ever forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hugging him) Oh, Teddy. We missed you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were always our number one son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes) Mom, Dad. This display of unconditional love is appalling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are a FAMILY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A family, need I remind you, that HE ridiculed and left for dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut your pie hole, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not have my boys arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, when I'm seventeen, can I turn everyone's life upside-down, behave like a total piece of canine excrement, and then wipe the slate clean with a half-baked apology and a Kodak moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is precisely why I got the rights to my new room IN WRITING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his parents) I need your help.  I'm really in deep shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say "shit," honey. Use the strong vocabulary God gave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, there's no problem too deep or too shitty for us to solve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad reaches for a can of peaches from the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, it's a simple fix. The only difference between my store and that magazine of yours is a bunch of zeros. Now, have I ever told you the story about the can of peaches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "Heaven" stockholders' meeting in progress. Uncle Billy stands at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies, gentlemen. "Heaven" has gone to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind him are charts, wall graphs. We quickly realize he a complete and utter turn-coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved my brother. I stood by his wishes to let his son run the company. A son he never knew. A son that he and his wife gave away at birth. A son who was raised in a world quite different from our own. Nevertheless, I was there for the lad. I guided him as best I could. But he's only seventeen, with a mind of his own and judgment that is, well, frankly, not a chip off the old block. There is only one clear solution... (gesturing to himself) And I think we all know what that is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --PEACHES! CANNED PEACHES!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted bursts into the meeting with his Dad. Holding up a ca peaches. Suddenly hundreds of eyes are upon him. Curious, bewildered.  Ted dashes to the podium, with passion in his soul and fi in his belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job. Back off, Benedict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy steps into the shadows as Ted looks out at th crowd. He's petrified. But he takes a deep breath and fin the courage to explain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only man I called "Dad" owns a little grocery store in Xenia, Ohio.  He learned a lot of cool stuff from my Grandpa, who was a peach farmer in his day. Grandpa knew the right thing to say in every situation, and it usually involved peaches. My dad's a lot like him. And he taught me, you have to focus on the peachy side of life, not the pits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's eyes are filled with tears. He's never been so prou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a time when canned peaches were the hottest, greatest thing ever invented. It was like a little taste of summer, anytime you wanted. Grocery stores couldn't keep them in stock, they were so popular. And even though other canned fruits like pears, plums, and pineapples have come along, people still need to know they can get their canned peaches, on the same shelf, whenever they want them. It's comforting, you know? It fulfills their expectations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stockholders are listening. Uncle Billy grins nervous Unable to believe Ted is pulling this off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably wondering if there's a point to all this and I guess it's just that I goofed last month. I not only moved the canned peaches, I restocked the shelves with kiwi, guava, and mandarin oranges in heavy syrup. I challenged people's expectations.  And you can't do that to your customers. So, I ask you for one more chance to fix things and give our readers back their canned peaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stockholders APPLAUD enthusiastically, giving Ted a standing ovation. Ted turns to Uncle Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for teaching me an important lesson. What makes a family is love, not blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is fair in "Heaven," Ted-baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. And guess who's the new King of the Unemployment Line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on, kid. Throw me a bone. I'm your uncle for gosh sakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks at pictures. Layouts. Reads copy. Listens to hi staff. He seems confident. In control. Mature beyond his years. The magazine goes to press. In VOICE OVER, we hear Julie, reading the article about Ted that she wrote for t school paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It's easy to fall prey to petty jealousy when considering the young life of Ted Nelson. But how would any of us behave if one day all our dreams came true? Would we handle it half as well? Would we find ourselves making the same mistakes for which we criticize him?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone hands Ted a copy of Julie's article. He reads the last portion of it aloud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "One can only hope that Ted Nelson will find bigger and better dreams upon which to set his sights as the years pass. And that he will remember, always, where he came from."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie opens her front door. Charlie grins. He hands her a copy of "Heaven."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intrigued, she turns to the page.

dialogues.speaker: MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: We see a special dedication, "To Julie, My Partner in Cri With All the Love in the World." Julie's eyes fill with tears. She flips ahead to "The Girls of Xenia" pictorial, only to find-- Principal Merkin. Singing his heart out, in drag as Barbr Streisand. It's a series of shots from the Cincinnati nightclub. Other shots suggestively include him with Moll the foreground, as if they posed together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad for a hack. He has a future in yellow journalism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kicked major ass and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin drives. The RADIO plays in the b.g. As o song ends, we hear the DJ say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's for you Dick Merkin of Tecumseh High. From all your students. With hugs and kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice of Barbra Streisand fills the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "People/People who need People/Are the luckiest people in the world."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin pales.  He turns off the radio.  But somehow, he can still hear the song.  As he pulls into th school parking lot, students wave enthusiastically.  He w back tentatively.  Anxiety rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin swings open his car door to be greeted b the sound of Barbra singing her heart out through the par lot. Every student's car stereo blasts the song. Students CHEER. Chanting:  "BAR-BRA, BAR-BRA, BAR-BRA!"  Principal Merkin turns crimson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graduation caps fall all around. People hugging, laughing overjoyed. Ted searches for Julie, but she's nowhere in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big graduation party in progress. But Ted sits in the corner, looking sad, dejected. Julie didn't show up. He b it. Jimmy and Charlie approach, with cheering on their mi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why so melancholy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were born naked, wet, and hungry. Now you're hip, handsome, and rich. You are the coxswain on the ship of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat, Drink, and Screw Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) I taught him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From my wise, albeit youthful, vantage point, the world is your oyster. You scored big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got everything you ever wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except the girl. The only one that really mattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who might that be?  Miss July? Miss August?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted turns to find Julie. His faces brightens with hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie, wow. I was afraid you left. I was afraid I'd never see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going anywhere, Ted. You're the one with the champagne wishes and caviar dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I decided to let Helen run the magazine. I need to go to college, learn a few things, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie seems pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I thought maybe I'd take up boating. I've always wanted to be a "coxswain."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very ambitious. I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, I'll need a first mate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where you can find any number of naked girls who'd love to hop on board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All kidding aside, he speaks from the heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie, you were right. All the naked girls in the world mean nothing. It's the one you want to cover up with your coat that you really love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie smiles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Planet Ted. Five years from now. What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I graduated from college. Did great, summa cum laude and all. And I'm about to launch a brand new magazine called "EXPOSED!"  An homage to Miss Julie Conroy of Xenia, Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where you can find an excellent editor-in-chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow pages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let your fingers do the walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the music changes. "People." Ted grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're playing our song.  (extending his hand) Dare I ask for this dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hand) You better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Julie begin dancing and kissing in the b.g.    Charlie and Jimmy feign tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sucker for a happy ending. (hugging Jimmy) Hold me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we start to RISE AGAIN, above the NELSON HOUSE, into clouds above Xenia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, as you can guess, everybody pretty much lived happily ever after. My parents didn't give up the grocery store...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We descend through clouds and quickly find we're...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad take pictures and smooch in front of the pala

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but they did manage to sneak away for a second honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: ON A NEARBY NEWSSTAND
dialogues.text: We ZOOM CLOSE on "Heaven Magazine," where pages flip open the wind, revealing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merk's appearance in "Heaven" turned out to be a good thing. He was spotted by a talent scout...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Merkin dressed as Barbra, singing "Don't Rain o Parade."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and went on a European summer tour, fulfilling his lifelong dream. Naturally he brought Poochie, the only girl he ever really loved.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WINGS
dialogues.text: Poochie, the Cocker Spaniel, watches. Wagging her tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After graduation, Charlie moved to Utah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie wrestling in a haystack with the IDENTICAL TAYLOR TRIPLETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...where he married all three of the identical Taylor Triplets. Let's just say, they've been very busy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peeking out of the haystack, we spot at least a dozen CHA JR's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And even Uncle Billy landed on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Billy wears a phone headset. He seems to be swimmin a sea of "Time-Life" style operators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...with a two year subscription to "Heaven," you get a free underwater calculator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now if you'll excuse me, I think I'll get back to being the coxswain on the ship of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Julie sail off into, what else but a GLORIOUS SUN
